This is pretty neat! A few follow-up questions come to mind as to how one could adapt this approach to some of my favorite wordle variants:

1) What if you're allowed to guess ANY five-letter string? Certainly some obscure, meaningless 5-letter combination should get you better results than, say CRATE or SALET, but with 26^5=11,881,376 allowed guesses you couldn't possibly brute-force that in a reasonable amount of time. Is there any efficient way to search for a 5-letter string which gets as close as possible to a uniform distribution, given a set of remaining possibilities and corresponding weights? And just how much of an advantage would this be?

2) Dordle: how can you adapt this approach to optimize two simultaneous wordles? Here's some of my thoughts:
- It's pretty reasonable to assume the two wordles are independently distributed (even though they're guaranteed to be distinct, the difference in results should be negligible). As a result, the expected information of the 2-wordle system can be very well-approximated by the sum of the two expected-infos. And the entropy of the 2-wordle system can be very well-approximated by the sum of the two entropies. In fact, by tracking the intersections of the two possibilities-sets, you should even be able to make this exact.
- Total entropy seems like a fair heuristic, but let's say I wanted to refine this to approximate expected remaining guesses like Grant does here. How could you derive some estimate for the expected score that takes into account the way entropy is split between the two wordles?
- The question then extends to n-ordles - for large n you'll probably start seeing a brief exploratory phase that can perhaps be optimized, followed by a series of guesses which are pretty much layups. I suspect the independence assumption would be optimal to avoid tracking large numbers of intersections. And perhaps an approach based on weighted averages of entropies might be appropriate as well.

If you're still reading this, lmk your thoughts. I'm in the process of making a wordle-bot, and I'm hoping to adapt it to also handle some of these variants.

ok so I don't know wordle and most of my idea is on presumption that all English words are used
1 (creating a database for all words) download the English dictionary and write a program to identify all 5 letter words
2 (1st word) identify the average consonance to vowels
3 let's say the consonance to vowels is 3:2 so we get the 3 most common consonance and 2 most common vowels
4 identify if/all words with those 5 letters (if no words math, replace the least common of the 5 with something else, keep repeating until a word or more is found)
5 compare all selected words to the other words, this is to see which word is most likely to have latters in the same position as others (you can technically just do this with ALL the words and find the best word, but that sounds like an impossibly long wait for the computer to process all that)
6 (Other word) depending on whether we are trying solve the puzzle as quickly as possible , we can start by choosing a word dependent on our previous word's results .Excluding certain words and following the same rules as for the first word, continuously until end
or
As accurately as possible, picking another word with the 4th ,5th, 6th most common consonance and 3rd, 4th most common vowels follow same process for the first word, for the 3rd and 4th words do the same or similar to the 2nd but with the correct letters in the right place. for the 5th and 6th it would best to start picking words most likely to be the right one

Fun stuff. Going through the first 145 Wordles, I see that the correct word is never a 4 letter word with an S tacked on the end. This might affect the ranking of TARES as a good opener.

I'm also interested in how WordleBot does on those occasional puzzles where you end up with 5 or 6 possibilities and only 3 or even 2 spaces to try them. E.g. archived Wordle 113. I got to WATCH on the third try, so I knew it was only the first letter that needed to change. I burned through MATCH, BATCH, and LATCH and got zonked. This left CATCH, HATCH, and with low probability NATCH untried. (PATCH had already been excluded by my guess of PATIO on line 2). Thinking over it, I realized that on line 4, I could have guessed CLIMB (assuming I don't have "hard mode" turned on which I don't.) If the C turned green, or the L, M, or B turned yellow, I'd know the answer. If not, I could eliminate CATCH, LATCH, MATCH, and BATCH and use my last two guesses on HATCH and NATCH (or PATCH if that hadn't been eliminated). How does WordleBot do on a puzzle like this?

This is great but very general, it assumes the answers are chosen as a human might choose them. If you really want to min/max the game, you should use the actual mechanics.

The actual game uses a fixed set of answers and all are equally likely to occur. I came up with a very simple way to rate the "best" starters. Simply put, you want to choose a starting word that, on average, leaves you with the fewest remaining possibilities. There are some inbuilt assumptions here, but it's a pretty good estimate.

And doing this is remarkably simple. For a given "guess", each of the equally likely solutions will yield a "response" from Wordle. If two solutions yield the same response then they are indistinguishable to the player. So to work out the expected number of remaining results for a given "guess", simply group all the solutions by their "response".

Now you have a set of possible "groups" of remaining answers. The chance of your guess yielding that group is the size of the group divided by the total solutions. So the expected value of each group is its size ^ 2 / total solutions. The expected value of your guess is the sum of the expected values or:

EXP_guess = SUM([G.size * G.size for G in groups(GUESS)])

You can run this for every possible word (about 12k words) to determine the best performing.

This can be done in about 40 lines of readable Python. It takes < 10s to run on a single thread. The top 5 words are ROATE, RAISE, RAILE, SOARE, ARISE and they average just under 11 remaining words after the first guess.

This doesn't take into account the chance of 1-shotting the problem, or the performance of the subsequent results (some sets might be easier to guess against than others). For a truly optimal answer, you'd have to brute force every possible game for every (reasonable) guess for every turn and average out the best results. But this will get you 99% of the way there and should be a fun challenge for any aspiring programmer to take on.

Very cool and interesting video on a topic that has interested me for several years now. Have you ever contemplated the application of the thermodynamic physics of cyclic heat engines to hypothethical analygous "information" engines? Consider that as you solve a wordle puzzle, from the perspective of the app software, which knows the answer ahead of time, shannon entropy remains constant throughout - there is only one answer to the puzzle. However, from the perspective of the player , a game starts at the minimum level of shannon entropy, increases as bits of information are radiated to the player through the process of solving culminating in the high shannon entropy state of the player "knowing the answer" . Then the slate is wiped clean, back to the original minimum level of shannon entropy as a new game is started and the player is hooked - Can Work be extracted from this cyclic "entropy drop" just as it is from a carnot engine? By working to develop "the ultimate algorithm" are you increasing the efficiency of the engine's operation up to the physical limits? By playing are you not fulfilling the role assigned to you as a sort of macroscopic "Maxwell's Demon"? Is this just one small example of how the global telecommunications industry operates? Is it all exploitation of the player by that future capitalistic AI computing against the 2nd Law cooky Nick Land wrote about? Does the Catholic sacrament of Confession decrease Shannon entropy? Are forgiven sins forgotten bits of information? Are Heaven and Hell isoentropic systems only Hell is hotter? I'd write a paper if I cared about formalities and if peer reviewers were actually open to the idea that the 2nd law isn't all that its cracked up to be.

Dear 3B1B
Firstly thanks for great video, I'm a fan of your work and Manim!
Since I'm working in chemistry, I wanted to let you know that from a chemical POV the work "Entropy" actually makes a lot of space. In thermodynamics, entropy is actually not a measure of chaos (as it's often believed) but rather a measure of chaos-ability. Every system has some amount of energy (=information in your case), and the more ways of distributing energy exist, the higher the entropy. A bunch of pencils laying on the floor has higher entropy then the same number of balls, as the pencils chaotically thrown on the floor can assume more different patterns then spherical balls. It is just as you have shown at 13-minute mark: for 3^5 possible patterns the entropy is high, because the information (=energy in physical sense) can be distributed in various ways. But when there are only 8 possible patterns, the number of possible words (or in physics, the number of energy states that can be assumed) is limited, and as a result the entropy is low.
After this long introduction, in this sense I wanted to point out that the Figure presented at 12:38 is in my opinion wrong: since in both cases there are 70 red and 70 blue circles, the number of states (placements of circles) each figure can assume is the same, and thus entropy of both pictures is identical. Left and right figure are just different realizations of the same system, differently thrown pencils. BUT if you were to add some rules (which in chemistry would be interactions between gas/solid molecules, while here you could have rules like "red must always neighbor other red", with pencils it could be connecting some of them using string), the entropy would actually change.
I hope I made it clear, though it is difficult to do that with only text! If you 3B1B, or anyone other, would be interested in the subject, hit me up using private message and I'd love to discuss it further or suggest some sources! Have a great day!

The position of letters is a factor.  For example, I prefer TALES over SALET ( SALET is recommended by others who have done computer analysis of this game) because if I do NOT get a green S, then that rules out a huge number of plural four-letter nouns with an S on the end, like BOOMS.  Note that I am getting a lot of information out an absence of a match  there.  Though Y is a fairly rare letter, it turns up at the end of a lot of five-letter words.    Letters like L, R and H are important beyond their commonness because they often combine with other consonants as in BLAND, PROSE, and CHAIR.

Your explanation doesn't touch on digraph and trigraphs, which if you understand how the presence of one known letter in a word impacts the likelihood of other letters being found in the solution, it can help improve your accuracy.

For example, if your first guess "hits" the letter R, then your chances of the word having a {B, C, D, F, G, P, T, W} in it go up somewhat, because the letter R often pairs with those letters. If your first guess hits the letter T, then you are more likely to see the letters H, R, S in the word. Etc. As well, if you pick a guess word that includes letters that make up half of a digraph, and that letter is not a "hit", then you can rule out all words containing the digraph incorporating the missed letter. For example, if you pick the word "DOUGH", and you don't get a hit on D, G, or H, then you know you can rule out words that have the common digraphs: LD, RD, GR, GL, ING, CH, CHR.

Also, some letters occur much more frequently at the start or end of a word. For example, the letter K is more often found at the end of a word than in the middle or at the start.

My reasoning for crane was that I have heard that E is the most popular vowel so I need that one immediately. Then usually most five-letter words I have come across tend to have 2 vowels. So my best guess as to what the second most popular vowel is is A. Then I wanted to choose 3 common consonants to go along with the A and E and the most common ones that came to mind were T,C,L,R,N.D. and so I made a word out of C,R and N consonant and A and E for vowels.

I just skipped through this video right now and see you have an algorithm choosing the best word and I am guessing it did a similar process of choosing the most common occurrences of letters in a 5 letter word and it's pretty awesome to see that computers reasoning lines up with just general common sense reasoning too.

Anyway though wordle is fun. And double fun to take seriously and use your brain to as big brain mode as you can. The fun little strategy behind it is awesome to see others enjoying too along with myself LOL.

There's one thing that the "math nerd" in me is finding unsatisfactory / that I need clarification over. Around 9:55-10:20, you describe that "if one observation cuts your space by 1/4th (2 bits of info), and another observation cuts it by 1/8th (3 bits of info), then both observations cut it by 1/32th (5 bits of info)". But to me, this would seem to be the case only if the two observations are "independent". If there's a correlation (say, all words that "start with s" also "have a t"), then the two observations put together won't give you 5 bits of information. Right?

What is throwing me off about that is basically how we are able to then claim that "information adds up" [when defined as information = "number of bits" / -log(reduction in sample space)].

Is there a wee bit of an oversimplification there? Could there be some other kind of "definition of information gain" that isn't this, but has the property of measuring the reduction in the possible sample space well?

So the way i understood your explanation is that you dont want to choose common letters as, if it shows it gives not much info (since it`s common) but if it doesnt show then it excludes a lot of words so it gives a lot of info. Same goes with least common letters. If it hits, you cut out a lot of words but if you dont hit it tells you little. So a letter that would cut off half of the words is best. At least for just one letter. Then the second and other letters follow the same pattern. But you want to prioritize letters that share the least amount of words together so each one will reveal as little redundant information as possible.

I watched some of this video, scanned the rest. The problem with this methodology is that if the best first word is always "Crane" per this mathematician, the 2nd best word to try (for information) will be based on what correct letters (either green or yellow tiles) show up when using "Crane." But since no one is doing this by computer each day, one needs to use (if they want to use the so-called "elimination" method) two consistent first words, for the first two tries.

My non-computer methodology, is to use the SAME first two words everyday, and by doing this, I am batting 70% - 75% in getting the word in the 3rd/4th try. Way better than the 50% average (3rd/4th tries total combined) notated during the video. (Shown from the Wordle twitter feed.) The two words I use? "Sonar" and "Tuile."

The obvious reasons are that this gets all vowels, even the less used 'U," as well as using the 5 most used consonants in the English language. The less obvious reasons is that in "Sonar," the vowels are in the 2nd & 4th positions -- common for 5 letter words -- so I'll frequented get one of these immediately. And with Tuile," the vowels are all in good placement here too.

The problem with "Crane," is that 'A' is in the middle, so not the best placement for 5 letter words. (Though 'E' is in good placement.) And 'C' is not in the top 5 most used consonants, so that is not advantageous either.

I think the word 'AROSE' is a better first guess. I counted, or rather had my computer count, the number of times each letter in the alphabet occurred in the 12,918 five-letter words in the English language. The top five letters, in order of descending occurrences, are 'S', 'E', 'A', 'R' and  'O'. The only word that includes these five letters, and thus allows for the highest probability of obtaining a hit, is the word 'AROSE'.  The word 'CRANE' includes the letter 'N' (9th place) and the letter 'C' (13th place) while it does not include the letter 'S' (1st place, 5916 occurrences). Including an 'S' will  almost exactly eliminate ½ the words in the list by itself.

Wordle doesn't use plurals.  It allows you to guess them, but the answer is never a plural unless the word only exists in plural form.  So nails, maths, volts, etc are all useless.  And as S is most commonly at the beginning if it's not at the end, you're best to start with an S word in your first two guesses.

I am pretty certain you can get an average lower by considering other factors. For example, consider the letter 't' and its position. I have not looked at the Wordle list but knowing a bit about English in general I'm quite certain that 't' appears in the first and last positions much more often than it appears in any other position. That's due to English digram frequencies such as 'th' and 'st". The combination 'ts' is extremely rare in non-plural words, for example. So all guesses containing 't' do not contain the same amount of information, I think.

My own strategy is based off letter frequencies more than word frequencies, which is why I always use 'their' as my first guess. ETAOIN SHRDLU for the win.

Instead of searching over the space of all words for the best first word, one might lower the expected number of tries by searching over the space of all pairs of words for the best two words to start with.

I made my own wordle program to determine a set of a few words that would be the best guesses to make, regardless of the information you got from a previous guess. That is to say, it came up with about 5 words that you could theoretically guess every time and get optimal results each time.

I used entirely different metrics to measure the value of a word, given that I'm a novice at this and it was mostly a fun programming exercise for me, but I still managed to get tares as the best first guess, which is really nice to see! :)

What is not explained is why the "x" in the summation at 14:15 in the video is the correct variable by which to bin answers and sum over. For example, you could have chosen other numerical properties of a guess. By listing the patterns horizontally from least information to most, you have encoded in that axis the amount of information in a response. This is why the graphs decrease as you move to the right.

The answer lies in what information you are given back by wordle. I think that there should be a way to measure the information content of a given pattern, and plot versus that quantity.

My approach was similar but less rigorous. For me, the first two guesses are most about ruling out common letters. I found a list of 5 letter words, analyzed letter frequency with an Excel function, and found a common (easy to remember) key word that gave the most average character information. Um, in re the words in the English language that start with a w, end with a y, and have an r in them ... you omitted the very word you were looking at: "weary". What you really meant was the five-letter words that start with w, end with y, have an r as the 2nd or 3rd letter, and don't have an r as the 4th letter ... and even then your list is incomplete ... e.g., it omits "warty", which is even on the Wordle list, so I don't know where you got those 3. (Edit: Upon further reflection, you must be excluding words containing a or e, so what you really meant was the words that fit the information you had from the Wordle clue/feedback, which is very different from what you said.) Here's a complete list of five-letter English words that fit your original description: warby warly warry warty watry weary werry whory wiery wordy worky wormy worry wryly wurly

BTW, I get near optimal Wordle results by picking the word with the minimal variance (sum of squares of the bucket sizes / number of buckets).

at t=26:04 , I think your expected score calculation double-counts some of the entropy. You're trying to calculate the expected score of your game if you guess "words" by summing (prob. "words" is correct)*4 and (prob "words" isn't correct)*(4+f(current entropy - expected entropy of guessing "words").

Your model estimates the information value of guess "words" at 1.27 bits, but that includes a 58% chance that "words" is the answer and you get all 1.44 bits right away. If we're evaluating the case where "words" is incorrect, we should exclude that from our distribution, which should make the expected value less than 1.27.

27:42 You could make a really helpful infrographic that combines the simplicity of the bar approach with extra visual flair and information with the first infrographic approach you took. You could use a stacked bar graph where the height of the stacked bar at that level of uncertainty represents how many guesses on average are required at that level. Then, you could have each bar in the stack represent the proposition of those words around that level of entropy which you get in N guesses, and associate that with the colors of the rainbow. First bar is red, and ratio of the red baras's area/height to the stack of bars around that entropy level shows visually how likely you are to get it in one guess. Then, next one is orange and the ratio of it's area to the stack is similarly proportion to how likely you will get it in two guesses, etc etc. In fact, added bonus, the ratio of the area/height of all the bars up to some point would represent visually how likely you are to get the word in as many guesses as the topmost bar represents or less!

Very cool video, it put in information theory terms some of my intuition with word choice. I think an alternative version of this algorithm could be made using meta information about English word structure rather than a set list of possible word choices. When I play I prioritize vowels and always start with ADIEU, because there are only 5 vowels, most words have 1 or 2, and the number and identity of the vowels give you more clues about the word. For example, if there is one vowel it will most likely be in the middle, and with two vowels they will most likely be in position 2 and 4. Some combinations commonly go together, such as EA or OI, and others are less likely such as EU. If I get no vowels on ADIEU then my second guess is MOORS to eliminate the OO, identify the most likely location of the O, and S, R, and M are all common letters. Some letters are highly positionally dependent, such as S likely being in the 1 or 5 position. Q will almost always be in the 1 position, and is always followed by U. There are also common syllables and consonant clusters in English; SH, SL, ST, SP, and SN are all very common but SV, SM, SJ, SZ, and SX are not. To combine this together in an example, an O in position 3 would help me narrow down the end of the word to sounds like OLE, OCK, OTH, OGH, ONS, OWN, etc. Having one additional consonant would narrow down the possibilities much more, for example an H would always go at the end (O-H) and not adjacent (OH-).
I play on hard mode and can typically solve in 3 guesses, but this strategy has weaknesses such as the IGHT ending; you can solve this on round one and still not win due to many possibilities for the first consonant (L, R, T, F, S, M, N, W). Anyway if you're looking for a challenge and want to dig into the "rules" of the English language, that'd be my recommendation.

One issue that many people have not taken into consideration is the fact that this list is human curated, and words with more common letters like A and E might actually be far less common to appear explicitly because the curator is a person who knows that many people are likely going to choose words with the most common letters. Does the person choosing the letters pick randomly from the selected list, or do they consciously choose each day? (If the former then the rest of my post doesn't apply lol)

I'm guessing this could be accounted for by looking at all of the past words that were chosen as answers from the list of possible answers and seeing if there's some psychological frequency trend that diverges from the actual expected frequency of each letter, so has anyone checked this? We would have to make sure that the letters line up with what we'd expect if it were a random sample for the most part, because otherwise, it might be the case that uncommon letters are actually a fair bit more common than the letters we'd most expect and then this algorithm wouldn't be as optimal. For example, if the person choosing the words each day is generally tricky, they might use repeating and uncommon letters more often than if the word were randomly selected from the list, or if they're more accommodating then words with double letters might almost never appear and they might not think about which words would be interesting to have people guess so they'll be much more common words on average.

What this boils down to is that if there's a human element to the chosen words, then there could be an algorithm that gives a much better score than the one in this video (as excellently crafted as it was). I'd be interested in a program that studied the words that have actually been given on Wordle and compared the frequencies of those letters with the frequencies of all the possible answers (or all the possible 5-letter words) and then trained itself on the set with the new letter frequencies in mind, which would probably give it significant predictive power for new words if the same person is selecting them. A good machine learning algorithm could probably enable a fair number of 2-round wins in that case, no?

(With that said, this consideration could've already been dealt with in this video and it was just too unimportant to mention, or if the selected word frequencies already match with the actual frequencies in English then all is good and I like the algorithm a lot so my post isn't really relevant. It'd still be cool to see other people's algorithms and see if there are ways to even better improve it though.)

@3Blue1Brown I did an analysis of the POSITION of each letter in the available wordbank and found the most likely letter for each position to be "SAAES" which isn't a word. I actually determined the TOP 5 letters for each position and the TOP TWO by position are "SAAES/CORAE". Without repeating letters, this indicates that "CARES" is the best starting word bc it uses the 2/1/2/1/1 most common letter per position.
Regarding "CARES" if you add the instances of each position what would result in a green block you get 10668 and 25503 for a yellow block.
Comparatively, "CRANE" only yields 5408 greens and 21790 yellows.
Based on this data I would argue that the FIRST guess should be determined positionally without consideration of entropy, and afterward, let entropy take over.
With "CARES" as the first word, the default second word would be "POINT" which comes to 4/2/3/5/5 most common letter per position.
With "POINT" the only letters in higher position are the first position B at 3rd and in fifth position Y and D and 4th and 5th. The rest of the letters in my table are already accounted for.
I honestly think if we combined these methods an even better answer could be found. If you email me (phillips.shawn.m@gmail.com) I would love to work together on this!

I can't check if this has been raised in the prior comments, but the Wordle program doesn't allow guessing words that do not correctly place all letters already known to be in their correct position. I noticed that you did not follow this quirky rule. It does make a significant difference in choosing optimal algorithms.

Also of note, is that it's very similar to the old (1955) one-on-one commercial 5-letter word guessing game JOTTO and a game with various names such as MOO or Bulls and Cows, which was later appropriated without attribution by the commercial distributed Mastermind. In the early 70sMy Dad and I used to play Jotto on paper and the Moo game verbally while hiking. He wrote a Jotto game on a computer in ~1970 and alphabetized a dictionary word list by their reversed alphagrams ~1969 (so that a word like TUX with reversed alphagram XUT would be at or near the end of the list and BAA would be near the front after (its reversed alphagram is just BAA).

This Wordle game is similar to others that I've played. One of them was called Mastermind, which was played with some chips. The other game was easy to play with just paper and pencil: each of two players tried to guess a four-cypher number chosen by the other, by guessing several times. The first to guess the other's number wins. Each guess gets feedback: number of correct but misplaced cyphers ('injured') and number of correct and rightly placed ones ('dead'). No individual information on any one cypher. Cyphers cannot repeat in guesses or in chosen numbers.
Usually, a few well-chosen guesses are enough to guess right.

If were given our word has a ‘t’ in it say it has 3 bits of information reducing possibilities by (1/8).If were given a ‘s’ is in our word then say it also gives us 3 bits reducing our possibilities by (1/8).If every word in our sample space that has a ‘t’ also has a ‘s’ then having a ‘t’ automatically gives you a ‘s’.So it only really gives us (1/8) reduction so there probabilities won’t add.

Although I have just been playing this game for the past few days, I have realised the human brain works a lot different from the algorithm.

For firsts, time for computing and remembering words could be considered. While the system has the ability to remember all 13k words, a human generally doesn't.

More complications come into place as suppose the output of having the letter but not in that position is much more complicated to remember.

Just for example, I realised dealing with vowels and overall flow/pronunciation of the word helped me guess the word much faster.

Secondly, is this step wise computing really as good as we see it to be ?
What if we have a short strategy playing some opening words to finally drop on the final word vs. improving on the go

For example, the other and snails vs. Starting with crane. Where the outcome is not strictly the expected number of words remaining but the easier computation of the same (don't know how one could measure it but seems important).

Basically, can you elaborate or investigate whether starting with the highest entropy word is beneficial or making a strategy of 2/3 fixed words is better?

Also, how do we incorporate the time of solving the puzzle (by humans) into the same?

"Cares" is actually the best starting word for Wordle quantitively actually. 'c' at position 1 yields 920 Matches, 'a' at position 2 2260, 'r' at position 3 1197, 'e' at position 4 2323, and 's' at the position 5 a whopping 3950. This is a total match probability of 10,650 (nearly as large as the 12,947 Wordle lexicon). There is no higher probability in the given set.

A comment made me wonder, so after writing a simple Python script against a lexicon of 15918 5-letter words, obtained from dwyl/english-words on github (though might not be the fullest list), I found that the best word is likely actually "kaies" (and yes it's a word in the Wordle database) because against the Wordle lexicon of 12947 values, the word contains the greatest probability overall with a "k" at position 1 with 500 matches (2nd best), "a" at position 2 with 2260 (best), "i" with 1047 (2nd best), "e" with 2323 (best), and "s" with a whopping matching count of 3950 (best). Those are all the best matches for each respective value, the only compromises are the "k" and "i" which are their second best positions (but best relative to the other letters in their best positions). All that being said, I'm not sure what entropy "kaies" has (maybe someone could help me out with that) but by my calculation it's the best to use as your opening word. Quantitively speaking, that's a respective matching count for "Kaies" of 9955 vs "Crane" of 5400.

And I've solved about 2/3rds in 3 guesses and 1/3rd in 4. (A 5 because I didn't know there could be double letters). And I've played about 30 times now.

I think it's unavoidable to get into situations sometimes where there are a few possibilities, just with rhymes, like smack-snack-slack-stack. But, almost always, they are solvable within 4. I think you have to use a good test word that narrows down the possibilities.

Something, that I particularly enjoyed from that video was at timestamp 23:55 he said that "tares" was the best choice, according to his algorithm, but he ignored that top choice and chose "favor" "because," as he said, "we can't let machines rule our lives."

That may sound like a bland line, but it was deeply meaningful to me. (I am pretty sure I am reading too deeply into it, because the real reason he picked "favor" instead of "tares" was probably because it happened to work out particularly nicely for the example he wanted to describe, but let’s pretend that that wasn't the case 😊.) Keep in mind that he hadn't finished optimizing his algorithm, so it’s not like he was distrusting the laws of mathematics in his choice to pick “favor” instead of “tares.” Also, even if he had finished optimizing his algorithm, I don't agree with the rules that he used to optimize it. (I think that he should have optimized his algorithm to win within 3 (or 2) guesses the most often, rather than optimizing to have the lowest average score (the difference is subtle, but important to me), but that is besides the main point I want to make in this post. LOL) He had probably picked "tares" as his first choice many times before, so that was probably already a well explored path. By picking "favor" instead, it might be that he was using his intuition to explore a different path. Often, we get so used to just doing what we think is supposed to be the most optimal path that we forget to listen to our intuition or forget to listen to God. Sometimes when we ask God a question, through prayer, we get an answer that seems much less than optimal, but that may just be because our optimization algorithm is flawed, compared to God's optimization algorithm for our lives.

But then, do we do the opposite? Do we always trust God and never trust in the optimization algorithms we made with our own mental strength (the plans we made ourselves for our lives)? Well... that is a tough question, for a bunch of reasons, one of them being that the question is worded deceitfully. When that question said "do we always trust in God..." that gave the impression that God always has an opinion on what the best choice is for every decision that we do. That is a false assumption. There are many things that God wants us to get the correct answer for from Him, through prayer, but for most decisions in our life, He doesn't care one way or the other. We will not know which He cares about and which he doesn’t unless we pray, study the scriptures, and listen to the promptings of the Holy Ghost speaking to our mind/heart (which promptings many people just think of as just being part of their intuition).

Also, the question of, "do we always trust in God, instead of our own thoughts," is deceivingly worded, because it implies that following God's answers to our prayerful questions will remove our responsibility to think for ourselves. In actuality, most of the answers I get from God come to me as I am researching to find the answer to a question, especially if I pray to ask for inspiration before the start of my research session. Also, when I am praying, most of the answers I get from God come in the form of, "did you think to research or check that one thing?" I do sometimes get answers that say "yes" or "no," and sometimes, to my shame, I have lived to regret ignoring those answers, but "yes" or "no" answers are rarer for me, personally. Also, God often does not immediately give answers to questions in the form of "what should I do about this?" because often God wants us to try to think of a solution for ourselves and then go back and ask a Him a question in the form of, "Heavenly Father, I have such and such problem and I think I should do such and such plan to fix it for such and such reasons. Should I do that plan? What do you think about it?" To ask a question in that form often requires a lot more thought (and personal growth) to ask, compared to asking a simple question of "what should I do about this?". He is our Father in heaven so he wants his kids to grow.

It is important to God's plan for us that we try different things, sometimes make mistakes, learn from our mistakes, use the Atonement of Jesus Christ to have our sins be washed away, and learn to trust God's plan through our own experience. God doesn't want mindless robots in heaven with Him. Heavenly Father wants his children (us) to trust him, in heaven with Him, not because we are forced to trust Him, but because we have decided, on our own, through experience, that we want to be the type of person/people who trust Him. Unlike mindless robots, we can make decisions for ourselves and choose to follow God's will, because we trust Him, when God's will is applicable to the situation.

This is great! Wordle, not so much,

* The misspelling of words is horrific. "Color" & "favor" are not words, they are bastardizations of words that have lost all practical meaning in the spelling.
* Words which should not exist by the "no proper nouns" rule are allowed, such as "genoa". Meanwhile words which are even less specific in their proper usage, such as "norse" are banned. If you're going to allow one set of disambiguations, you have to allow ALL disambiguations.

Best opener I've found so far,

* OPALS into LAHAR if L & A, into HORSE/SONET if S & O. No consistent rule for handling P & L, but getting an R & E in the second word are really good.
* The basic assumption is that E exists so commonly in English, it's easier to come up with a word that includes E than does not. Therefore we assume E exists for the first guess, and focus instead on the other common vowels.
* P, L, & S are often conjunctive consonants, so knowing if they are not present is super meaningful. S being at the end is a huge lock for example on a massive number of plurals. That "LS" combo at the end is an instant lock for a number of guesses for example.

I believe you should be maximizing expected information gain in the second part of the talk where you account for non-uniform word distributions. This is only equivalent to the entropy of the patterns in the case of uniform word distributions. I believe this is why -- in the second part of the talk -- subtracting the information of the pattern from the entropy of the initial word distribution does not equal the entropy of the resulting word distribution.

the optimal solution to wordle is to go through every word and treat it as a guess, and then pair it with every word again, as if that were a potential right answer, and then measure the average "elimination count" of possible right answers that would be eliminated from consideration where those to be a given guess and answer. the best guess is the one with the highest average elimination count. you don't need to convert this to an "entropy"; it's just a number. however the one useful thing in this video that i can't believe i missed, was that when calculating the scores, you can "cache" them given many pairs of words will produce the same result (e.g. black-green-orange-black-black).

I wonder what the optimal min/max strategy would be for a version where the person who "chose" a word could after each guess freely choose any word that was consistent with all clues given thus far, and where the "guesser" would be limited to picking guessing words which were consistent with the clues just given?  While one would think that the chooser would want to minimize the amount of information, the requirement that all guesses be consistent with clues would allow the guesser to fall into a "trap".  For example, if the first guess was "TAILS", which would seem reasonable since it has two vowels and three common consonants, the chooser could trap by awarding four green squares: "_AILS", and keep giving four green squares as a clue until all 11 words of that form had been guessed.

Great video! There is another notion of entropy that is more relevant to the problem at hand: guessing entropy. This came about when people started looking at brute-force guessing games (e.g., Wordle if there was no max of 6 guesses) and wanted to find the minimum number of expected guesses that's needed to find the correct solution. There is some relationship between (normal) entropy and guessing entropy but guessing entropy has proved to be of much more use in things like guessing passwords, etc. I wonder what would happen if we redo your code using guessing entropy, rather than entropy.

Actually, you are dead wrong. The information itself is -p*log2(p). If an event happens ALL the time (p==1), there's no information. If an event happens never (limit as p->0), there's no information. All of this was derived from scratch from simple principles by Shannon. The information of two independent events is equal to the sum of information of the two events individually. The information of any two events is always less than the sum of the information of the two events. The information content of p==0 is the same as p==1 and is zero. That's enough to get the correct formula for information (up to a scale factor). Thus the information in a fair coin flip is 1 bit, when scaled to -plog2(p). An unfair coin always has less than one bit, with a truly fixed coin having no information at all.

There's not much difference between using log(1/p) as the metric for information opposed to just 1/p, or p, or even just the number of valid possibilites left (n) which you need to calculate p in the first place. The answer is certain both when the accumilation of "bits" or possibility reductions corresponds to the total number of possibilities. Using log(1/p), 1/p, p, or just n in the calculation is purely a stylistic choice and, ironically, gives no information.

I've made myself a wordle solver by using Excel.
First, I got a txt file contain all English word from a github page (you can find it by using google).
Second, I pasted all the word to a excel column and filtered to get only 5 letters length word and split it into five letters column.
Thirdly, I created 26 alphabet letter column check if it exist in the word.
At this point, you've already got a simple wordle solver by just using filter. Splitted Word column filter as exactly or inexactly position. Alphabet check column filter as contained information.
Then, I copied and pasted everything as value because this file is over 18MB and my 8GB ram pc can't work probably.
Next, I count each letter for each if it exist in those words and sum it in a row and divide by the number of 5 letters word. I ranked alphabet letters for its frequency. I've found out letter frequency wiki only show all the English word not 5 letters word.
Because I got it from all English word, some words maybe not work.
Finally, I gave a point for every alphabet letter base on its rank and summed up point of each word/row and rank its summed point and sort it to find the most popular one.
The most one are from 5 letters a, e, i, r, s. I would tell you why my first guess is Serai and the extra work but I'm lazy.
My guesses are #1 serai, #2 clout, #3 nymph. It's worked like a charm for 2 first guess, you don't need the third one if you are desperated. Unlucky, sometimes it is just a different letter.

CRANE - makes more sense to a program running permutations and to increase the odds of a 3 guess word.

However, to guess a word, I propose, is different. It seems like your brain, like my own, mostly follows the logic that is "Hard Mode". Hard mode, you have to follow the previous clues. It seemed like your algorithm was following prior right answers.

If you have a 2 word starter, say CRANE - JOUST (just an example), you would be covering nearly every vowel and common letter. You would have 10/26 letters. This is a "Don't lose" strat, which is different from knowing word/letter frequencies.
RANE in CRANE are in common spots for words, but that is a danger to the human mind. You can start
CRANE and go to
TRADE
GRAPE
BRAVE
ERASE
FRAME
Common is statistically great place to start, for computers. It's a part of machine learning. Usually unique events are part of human learning and intuition (filling in the blanks).

IN fact, if you want to play Hard Mode, just start with JOUST and then go CRANE. It should work more than half the time.

So, to NOT think as a programmer for a second. Words are made of sounds and we tend to think not in letters, but in the smallest unit of sound that has meaning; syllables.
In part, at 5 letters many of the words are uniquely one syllable. But not all and I would caution that CRANE leaves essential letters in spots that make a lot of syllables. A and E can nearly go anywhere and be a part of sound. It might be smarter (for a human brain) to use a word like AISLE that isolates the A and E from each other. You'd still have the information on the 2 most common vowels and as a bonus add a 3rd and get the S, one of the most common consonants.

Anyways, given the proclivities of the human equation, I think less common starter words (less common in structure, sound and even appearance) will help most people.

This isn't about efficiency, just not failing. And I still think if we're trying to never fail, 2 words/10 letters are your best start.

Would it improve the bot to weight the score of a word based on how many other words would yield at least as much information.

So for example if your guess is SLATE and the S and A are yellow than any word of the form S_A__ is at least as good as SLATE. In addition, some of those words probably give MORE information than SLATE.

So when we're looking at the information we get from each possible outcome of a guess, we could score that outcome by how few other guesses would have given us at least as much information.

If a word's possible outcomes has a low number of other words that would give more informative results, it may be a better guess than a word that has more bits of information but has many words that give more informative results. This seems like maybe a better way to break ties between guesses.

Hoping someone will read all of this:

after this incredible video I saw a brooklyn 99 compilation and came across the infamous puzzle by captain raymond holt:

You have 12 men on a remote island, all of them weight the same except one, which weighs higher or lower (you don't know which one), on the island there is no scale but there is a seesaw, how can you determine which person is the person which doesn't weigh the same in 3 uses of the seesaw?

if you have came upon this puzzle before and want to skip to the intresting part then read the last paragraph.

I have to admit that I gave up on that puzzle 2 years ago when I first incountered it but I gave it another shot, I started by doing the first best move u can make which is to weigh 3 vs 3 which is firstly counter intutive because you want to weight 6 vs 6 but if you think about it - it tells you absolutly nothing because you don't know if the unique person is heavier or lighter so you divide it 3 vs 3 and if the seesaw is equal then the unique person is at 6 men group you didn't weight, and then you have 6 men and 2 more attempts left, so you messure 2 of the remaining group vs 1 of the remaining group plus another one from the group where you know all people weight the same and then you can narrow it down to 3 persons and you have 1 more attempt to go and then you will get stuck, trust me. even getting here wasn't easy at all. of course that you can get lucky from time to time but the puzzle wants a bullet proof solution.

This is the intresting part, unlike next time I tried to solve this puzzle this time when I got stuck at the end I had this video in the back of my mind and so I have noticed two key points:
1. The best I manged to do each step of the way is cut in half the number of possible men
2. The seesaw is binary - it only tells you if a given group contains or not the unique person
From those two points I realised that the second point proves that the first is correct, because of the second point you are limited to learn 1 guaranteed bit each step. imagine the problem was with 16 men then each men can be coded with one 4 bit number and we will need 4 bit (or measures of the seesaw) in order to find the men. since 12 is bigger then 8 then it requires more than 3 bits and therefore the puzzle is impossible to solve!!! Intrestingly enough if you knew if the man is heavier or lighter then the seesaw will have 3 options and it will give you log2(3)=1.585 bits and you need log2(12) =3.585 bits and therfore since 3.585/1.585=2.262<3 you will be able to find the person in 3 uses of the seesaw!
Hope you liked it, it was fun to me:) great video!

I played Russian version of Wordle just once and got the right answer on my third guess by opening with Russian equivalent of the word “ocean”. Just one letter different from “crane” and it also hits 4 out of the most frequent letters in Russian language.

I got two yellow blocks from that guess and incorporated those letters into my next guess while switching their positions and trying different letters.

My next guess was a Russian five letter equivalent of the word “line”. It had two of top-5 letters by frequency and two of top-10 with an uncommon letter thrown in. One of the yellow blocks turned green, one stayed yellow and I also got an extra yellow and green blocks. At this point I got confused since I thought that each letter should be used only once in the final answer and there was no word that I knew of that would match the pattern I discovered.

Once I realized that the most likely answer had to incorporate the same letter twice, I went for the Russian equivalent of the word “theatre” and that was the right answer.

The game seemed too easy, so I never played again.

How much worse of an expected outcome do you get if the program always tries to win in the least number of moves possible? For example - you guess crane and know that there is an R in the word somewhere.  Your second guess in this seemed to never include the letter R, and thus there is a 0% chance you will get it right on the second try.  Of course the trade off is to learn more so that you have a better chance of getting it right on guess 3 and 4, but how much better is it?

I have a question about your video. at 12:57, you show a result of yellow, green, green, green, green for the guess slate.
Isn't that an impossible result? if you have 4 letters in the correct location, if the fifth is in the word at all, it MUST also be in the correct location right? You already know it isn't in any of the other locations.
I suppose that result is possible if you guessed a word with multiple instances of the same letter, so if you guess FIFTH, you could get a yellow for the first F, because it's in the word but not the first letter, and a green for the second F because that is where it belongs.
But in the example given, there are no repeat letters, which means that if 4/5 letters are in the correct location, and the fifth letter is in the word, it must also be in the correct location, because there is nowhere else to put it without dislodging one of the letters you already know to be in the correct location.

I liked your presentation relating it to information theory. However I think that you can squeeze more by considering also the distribution of letters in the qualified words. I wrote such an algorithm and my best first guess is RAISE. It gives lowest number of alternatives when all five letters are incorrect. I did make the assumption that knowing one or more correct letters is always better that not having any correct letters. Should correct letters appear then I consider it a lucky bonus.
RAISE reduces the number of possible words without correct letters to about 700. No other word in the five letter dictionary beats this result. Clearly, in the next step this process selects the ‘best’ word out of considerably smaller set. Since this is minimizing the most unlucky scenarios, the actual performance is in practice quite good. Working through this, I am to understand the following claims?
1) Probability, here, is the space of possibilities (number of outcomes) given an observation over the space of possibilities (number of outcomes) without any observations.
2) Information is a search through possibilities (and the formula assumes a binary search algorithm).
3) Bits are the number of search steps to reach the same space of possibilities/outcomes [singular] as a given observation. Aka, how many search steps are skipped, for which a brute force algorithm would otherwise take, as a result of the observation.
4) Entropy/Expected is the average information (average bits) for all spaces of possibilities/outcomes [plural].
5) The use of probabilities eliminates the need for the binary search to be pre-sorted.

This is super reassuring, I'm opting for an entirely different approach (rank options by taking each outcome as a bucket - i.e. 23 only match 3rd letter and rest missed - and summing the squares of the bucket counts, which I called average squares) and I consistently saw SOARE as a top first pick as I was going through fixing bugs, even though forcing CRANE was better. Right now I'm doing a full depth search limited to possible answer words only, which interestingly marks CRANE as failing on the 6 depth limiter. One note: almost no information theorist uses the notation I for the information random variable even though we use capital letters for random variables. The reason is that it clashes with the mutual information notation I(X; Y). Therefore, small i is more common.

This problem is closely related to the 20 Questions problem where you try to find the answer by yes-no questions, and its solution uses this “entropy maximization” idea. As Grant explained, by maximizing the entropy of each guess (he equivalently minimizes the remaining entropy of the unknown), he extracts the largest information possible from each guess.
There is one missing notational issue in the video. Let Y(x) denote the random pattern of guess x. We maximize H(Y(x)) in first guess. In the next guess, we observe the outcome y_1 and we maximize the remaining entropy given that we saw y_1. We use the notation max_x H(Y(x) | Y(x_1) = y_1) for that. Grant obviously did exactly this but didn’t use the proper notation which is acceptable considering the general audience.

That video is just awesome. Coming from someone who has been studying entropy in Physics, I say that this video can give us a real push about questioning entropy as statistical mechanical variable for small system.

One could use this program to describe the influence of initial states (in classical systems) on the production of entropy. I'm not sure, though, if that would be possible via your code, since it may require some refinement for its inner workings such as describing space or trajectory to have relevant probability amplitudes to infer most typical trajectory or even most probable trajectory, say, in the case of stochastic thermodynamics. For now, I leave that as a thought, because it may need more thinking than just saying it could be used.

By the way, I love the way you explained entropy and information, because even after years of using it, that was also illuminating and deep to me. When I first stumbled upon entropy, I was very skeptical, because it sounds a bit arbitrary, at least, the way Boltzmann initially defined according to textbooks. After a few years, I understood that he was looking for a probabilistic description to the dynamics of small parts of a macroscopical object and with Gibbs' help both constructed the basis of thermodynamics via statistical mechanics. However, it is still intriguing when we are speaking of non-equilibrium thermodynamics when trajectories of small systems comes to play as parameter for probability amplitudes and, for instance, we can come up with a definition for the second law in nanoscale that does not violate the second law in the macro scale, but it does hold a probabilistic meaning. Anyway, just a thought and my grain of contribution to a related topic.

Tell me if you think this method might be better

1. Using the list of all possible words (aka "TotalList") do the following:

2. Check to see the percentage of words that contain each possible letter.
(e.g. "A" == 0.16675, "B" == 0.08146, "C" =...)

3. Take the letter that is closest to 1/6 (appears in approximately a sixth of all words) and separate all of the words that contain it into a sub-list that is separate from the rest of the words.
»Be sure to also track of all of the other letters that were close to 1/6 and save them for later (e.g. a range: 1/5.5 ≤ x ≤ 1/6.5).
(Recommended: supposing the found letter was "A", name the list of words with "A" in it "ListA", and re-name the list of words without "A" as "SansAList".)

4. With those remaining words, repeat step 2 (bearing in mind that for one letter the percentage should be zero).

5. Repeat step 3, but instead of taking the letter that is closest to 1/6, take the number that is closest to 1/5.
»Be sure to also track of all of the other letters that were close to 1/5 and save them for later.
(Recommended: supposing the found letter is now "B" naming should be "SansAListB" and "SansABList")

6. Continue this pattern (i.e. 1/6, 1/5, 1/4, 1/3, 1/2) until you have 6 lists (hopefully they are approximately of equal size). This will be your first "SuperList", which consists of 6 sub-lists. 5 of these sub-lists will have a distinct letter that every word in that sub-list contains. The 6th sub-list will not have any words that contain any of those 5 letters.
(Recommended: supposing that the letters found were A B C D E naming should be "SuperListABCDE")

7. Working backwards through each most recently created sub-list, create as many "SuperList"s of sub-lists as you can by using the letters that were saved ("kept track of") in steps 3 and 5.

8. For each SuperList that was found, attempt to find viable words in the "TotalList" that consists of the 5 letters that were derived from each. Having "TotalList" in order will help dramatically.

NOTE: If a word cannot be found in "TotalList" that uses all 5 of the letters from a SuperList, that SuperList can be removed from memory. Continue until you find all viable words.

9. Calculate the delta value (aka "DV") for each of the remaining SuperLists from the "ideal" SuperList. How to calculate the "DV":
i. Take the count from all of the words from the original "TotalList" and divide it by 6 (let's call this count "SixthTL").
ii. For each SuperList:
get the sum of:
the absolute difference in size between the count of each its sub-lists and "SixthTL".
iii. The DV equals that sum.

10. Pick the SuperList with the smallest DV and use its found word(s) as your first guess.
-The SuperLists with the smallest DV have the "best" word(s) to start with, and the lists with the largest DV have the "worst" word(s) to start with.
-You should save the "top" SuperLists with for later testing.

11. Once you make a guess, you will select the relevant sub-list from the SuperList that was used, and save all of the "Confirmed" letters (and their positions) and all of the "Excluded" letters. This is done by searching for "Confirmed" letters (letters confirmed to exist in the answer) in order of how the SuperList was created.

For Example:
Starting with you::
The SuperList used was "SuperListLABDE".
The guessed word was BLADE.
And the game tells you::
The letters B and D were confirmed to be in the answer.
B is in the proper position (e.g. "P0").
D is in the wrong position (e.g. "P3").
Then you would save::
The sub-list "SansAListB" (as B comes before D in the chosen SuperList "SuperListLABDE")
Confirmed letters: B (and its position), D (and it's NOT position)
Excluded letters: L A E

Example 2:
None of the letters are "Confirmed" then the sub-list "SansLABDEList" would be selected.
Confirmed letters:
Excluded letters: L A B D E

12. Now you will efficiently make a new "TotalList" from the selected sub-list and the saved letters.
»Exclude all words that have letters that are "Excluded"
»Only include words from sub-list that contain the "Confirmed" letters, being sure to include what's known about their position as well.

13. Repeat the whole process over from step 2 to step 10, with this new "TotalList" starting point, in order to find the next guess, based on the results continue the process.

FINAL NOTE: Because the second round of guessing will be directly influenced by the first round of guessing, it is probably worth testing all the "top" first words (saved in step 10) many, many, many times to see how this algorithm performs with each of them.

I think this information theory approach is only counting appearance probability, but there are other pieces of language information that we can observe positionally. For example, we know that virtually every common English word has a vowel. One human method that a lot of people use is to rule out vowels, with strong words being ROUTE. If none of the vowels are green or yellow we know that A and I must be in the word, with the slight exception of maybe some rare words like CRYPT. We also know some positional things, such that if a vowel is in the center, then its likely to be preceeded by a consonant digraph. Im wondering if all of these English language quirks are actually captured by this information theory approach. Could we use digraph and positional knowledge to guess better as a machine?

19:31 I was working on a pet project to identify the depth of objects in a set of stereoscopic images, and I had the idea to use an organic shape for a selection of pixels to estimate the disparity of (instead of just a box or circle like you'd see in most papers easily found via Google), and I decided on the arctangent function for measuring the cut off criteria for the flood fill function used to select the pixel window to operate on. It seems sigmoid functions are just intuitively applicable to a lot of things. In my case, arctan probably popped into my head because of a history of having tried to use it for an aim bot AI, which unfortunately hadn't worked due to the context it was for requiring quaternion math (before I knew what quaternions even were, some 15 years ago).

It may be worth mentioning to other readers that the sigmoid function you chose appears to be the logistic function, and that other functions are considered "sigmoid functions" as well, including arctan(x) and even tanh(x). It seems referring to the logistic function as the "sigmoid function" is popular, however, at least when discussing NNs. I actually just checked my old (also around 15 years) NN code from when I was first learning about them, and it actually uses tanh for its sigmoid function.

My approach (average of ~3.585 total guesses):

1. Only use hardmode, delete any words that can't possibly be a solution from the list of guesses
2. Guess a word that gives the most "information" on average; words that have the least number of unique responses; more unique responses means you're less likely to get a response that actually reduces the possible list of solutions.
3. Use that response to cut eliminate words
4. Guess again.

Unfortunately, word #3 ends up being tied with a lot of other words, so I have hundreds of words that are "equally difficult" and can't easily rank words.

The starting word for this approach is always TRACE with this approach, but any of about a dozen words will get the same average within a few hundredths.

Also my personal, unassisted average is ~3.8 guesses

Great video, great ideas, etc., etc.

However, this problem was solved long ago.

We know the frequency of occurrence of letters in English. Sorted highest to lowest, it's something like ETAONS ...

Thus a good first choice is EARTH. A good second choice is SPOIL. Just use those two words all the time, although you could probably improve.

Then use your vocabulary skills, and a bit of reasoning. You should be able to win every time, peaked on 4 guesses.

One further point. If you have made 4 guesses, and don't really know the answer, your 5th pick should use as many unused letters as possible, even though you know it won't be the answer, to guarantee a win in 6 moves.

I noticed that the suggested first guesses tend to include A and E but no other vowels. My (human-based) strategy is a little different. I like to get AEIOU all nailed down in two guesses (even though U is less common) - it just helps my brain, since I'm not a computer. Something like ATONE would get the three most common vowels, but words with I and U are kinda rare, especially if you don't want to repeat a letter (DRUID, SUITS, etc. have repeats). So I tend to start with a word containing A, E, and I (loads of options: ASIDE, AISLE, etc.), and then get O and U in the second word, using common consonants that weren't in the first one. Because this is supposed to be fun, I mix it up a little, not using the same first two words all the time. (The first few days I played, I didn't repeat them at all, but that's impractical long-term.)

What’s fascinating is this has a direct connection with how information based decision trees are designed. But the splits we need to make are quite complex.

Separately, what’s interesting to me is that we’re actually conducting a greedy algorithm in the video. Let’s say there are two comparable word guesses that both limit the space to N possibilities. Right now we take a random one. But, an important question to ask yourself is: which of the N remaining possibilities is “nicer”. If you have N really crazy possibilities left, that would be worse than N really “nice” possibilities. This will be of course all based on empirics, on language itself. In the video a proxy is used which is the entropy of the remaining possibilities, based on the frequency of the words.

I love your explanation —- thorough and clear!

BUT I have a suggestion. Your approach seems focused solely on “letter frequency”. [Shades of Sherlock Holmes’ ‘Adventure of the Dancing Men’, where he uses ‘frequency analysis’ to crack a ‘substitution cypher’.] But in Wordle, information about ‘correct letter’ and ‘correct placement’ is provided. Your analysis mostly ignores ‘information re placement’.

Instead of a straight ‘frequency analysis’, why not an analysis of which letter in the possible words is most frequent in position 1, which in position 2, and so forth.Then search for words which have the sum of the greatest frequencies in each of the positions. Discard any words that have repetition of the same letter (like 2 S’s or 2 P’s, etc.) Would not this strategy maximize both ‘frequency analysis’ and ‘positional analysis?

I agree with you that utilizing the list of possible answers would be too much like cheating. [I was sadden to learn that the list of possible answers is so short.] But a similar effect can be had by rank the words by their ‘letter frequency’ and providing a cut-off of words that are uncommon. Of course, you face a ‘Sortie Paradox’ about exactly where to place the cut-off. You could just read through the list until you begin to read words whose meanings are unknown to you. But it would be a greater AI challenge to write an algorithm that would draw the line. I am still cogitating on what could be an effective criteria.

I realize Wordle was designed with limitations of “possible words” and “possible answers” in order to make the programming manageable. But, I think the game would be improved if ‘The New York Times’ who is acquiring the game would expand both lists to be the all words in some standard dictionary. I would vote for the OED, but then I have expansive dreams. Does NY Times (or a affiliated publishing company) publish a standard dictionary? If so, this would be an opportunity to tout its sales using Wordle’s popularity as a “hook” in advertisments.

Entropy is really useful in telecommunications:
Imagine a source is sending you 4 characters (A,B,C,D) with a 25% probability for each one that you have to codify in order to send them through a binary channel.

Since the source sends you each character with a 25% of probability, the entropy equals 2 bits, so you only need 2 bits in order to codify and send the message:
A: 00
B: 01
C: 10
D: 11
Of course you could use more bits to codify each character but that would be a waste of bandwidth.

There is no more efficient codification than this one, because the ratio bits/character equals the entropy.
Now lets imagine the source sends each character with the following probability:

A:70%
B:10%
C:10%
D:10%

In this case the entropy equals 1.36, which means that 1.36 bits is the minimum amount of bits necessary to send the information, of course we can only codify using complete bits, but instead of using the previous codification that has an average of 2 bits per character we can try another, for instance:

A: 0
B:100
C:110
D:111

In this case the average bits per character would equal:
0.7 * 1 + 3 * (3 * 0.1) = 1.6 bits/character as an average, with this new codification we managed to use less bits than the previous one.

As I said the limit is the entropy (1.36), we can create new codes that allow us to reach that by adding characters with each other:
AA:000
AB:001
BC:10001
.........

I hope you get the idea, by adding the characters and linking the most probable combinations of characters with the shorter number of bits we can achieve that the bits per character gets really close to the entropy, improving the efficiency of the transmission

I have designed a puzzle game that is kind of similar and relies on maximizing the information gain from each of your choices. However, I haven't found a way to formalize the optimal way to play the game. It'll be great to know your take on it. The concept of the game is like that: Suppose you are in an exam and you have to answer a set of True or False questions. Also, suppose you do not know the correct answers to any of the questions. In this situation, all you can do is random guessing and normally your chance score will be around 50%. Let’s say the teacher who marks your work gives you many more trials to answer the same set of the questions and you can peek at your total score at the end of each trial. What is the optimal way to maximize the information gain from your past trials to reach the perfect score with a minimal number of trials?
The obvious answer is to mutate the choices one by one and peak at your total score after each trial until your reach the perfect score. In this case, if you have 100 true and false questions. First, set all your choices to false and by chance you may get 50 correct answers. Then, change each of your false choices one by one to true and peek at the the total score again to see if your change increased the total score. This way you might need up to 100 trials to reach perfect score! However, if you mutate more than one question at the same time before peeking at your total score, it's possible to gain more information and reach the perfect score with less trials but it gets trickier as you mutate more questions at the same time. A conceptually similar game is available under the name MineClear.

Then noticing the mathematical similarity to the second law of thermodynamics and that there are countably finite possibilities for a given number of spatial manifolds it implies there must be a fundamental link between the volume of the spatial manifolds and entropy.

Another mention of how simulation show that for an initially expanding universe regardless of the initial distribution of the energy stress tensor across space the rate of expansion within voids will always exceed the local slowing of expansion due to matter. This is eerily similar to other systems of information economics neural networks etc. so perhaps gravity rather than being a conventional field is rather an effect of entropy maximization connecting to geometry.

Also the proof effectively shows that the highly symmetric analytically solvable Friedmann solutions to the Einstein field equations would thus correspond to the minimum possible entropy and represent a dynamically unstable singularity in time as ln(0) is not defined and thus can only exist in the sense of a trivial solution. there's another aspect: the above calculations, although very solid are good for solving this mathematically. That is, if you have a dictionary of the words and memory about how frequent they are.
Therefore, it is not necessarily good advice for humans trying to get better. The same way we can analyse a computer-vs-computer chess game and maybe even understand a few moves - but we can never hope to play like computers. Chess GrandMasters actually easily distinguish between "human" moves and "computer" moves (and can tell if they are being cheated, for example). The strategy for playing chess as a human is conceptually different and a whole paradigm inferior to computer chess. So, a really interesting analysis would be how to help a typical human solve wordle.

to be frank all i was looking for was at 29:06-> what's the optimal starting sequence that results in the most information gained on average? ok, so it's CRANE->SLIPT-> then what?. turns out there are only a few 5-unique-letter words remaining: junky, funky, jumbo, buxom, unbox, and kombu (which is a seaweed by the way). because this list is so short it should be memorized and the best one picked accordingly based on the outcome of playing CRANE/SPLIT. if you cant decide, just go with KOMBU. it can't be a coincidence why this word was highlighted in the video.

the reason why i am interested in optimal opening moves is because us regular humans are not like python scripts which have access to full word libraries. we might not be able to guess the best moves even after being provided with significant information like three yellows for example. if we always started with CRANE>SLIPT>KOMBU every single time regardless of information gained, i would wager that the typical human would be able to get par almost ALL the time.

Maybe this would be redundant in his program, but does it optimize for letter position?

For example a word with all vowels and an S in the middle might be a good guess, but S is the most common letter for a word to start with. Therefore, a word that starts with S then has a bunch of vowels would be better. (If that word existed.)

Similarly, what is the most common letter in the second position of a five letter word? Then third, fourth, fifth?

This could help get a better first guess. Then it might still be useful in the following guesses, but I'm even less sure about that.

Similarly, would it be redundant to optimize around what letters commonly go together? I-N-G, E-S, E-D, E-R, T-H, F-L, C-H, C-E etc. Is it more likely for a vowel to come after a consonant than another vowel? Or even letter combinations that you might not expect.

These letter groups could also be optimized like individual letters. ING is rarely going to be at the start of a word.

Some things I've discovered from full minmax explorations (no letter or word frequency heuristics, no information theory, just very optimised brute force):

No strategy exists that will always win in 4 guesses or fewer.

Many strategies exist that will always win in 5 guesses or fewer (in fact, you can start with ANY of the 12972 allowable guess words and still guarantee a win in 5 guesses or fewer).

As to what is the best opening guess, it really depends on how you define "best", but I don't think it's computationally feasible to calculate that, unless you relax the requirements on "best" and start guessing like this video. I really tried to compute the best word (i.e. the strategy that gives the best histogram, comparing histograms lexicographically from right to left) but 12972 is just such a very large branching factor. I gave up.

I imagine the top 3000 words of ngram frequency list will have fairly small correspondence with the real list.

In order the deal with the cryptic wooziness of it being a human curated list, I would propose putting a "common sense distribution" over the ngram list. Imagine a blank graph of probability vs ngram freq index and manually draw a curve over it, supposing super common words aren't terribly likely and neither are uncommon ones. I would guess a bimodal distribution, where the curator picks mostly words that are kind of common or kind of uncommon. I think this technique will make the source-blind approach score somewhere between it's current score and the "theoretical minimum"

So I saw this and went away and tried to code my own solution, and now I can usually get it in 3. Mine purely uses frequency analysis and foregoes entropy. Given that I knew it wasn't really possible to get it in 2, I knew I had to optimise the first 2 guesses as much as possible, so I generated all possible pairs of two words, and filtered them to only have the 10 most common english letters in. This gave me a shortlist of about 700 choices, I just had to work out which was best. The frequency analysis portion optimised my selections for yellows, now I just had to optimise for greens. I did a frequency analysis on which letter was the most common in each position of the words, then scored every pair based on how common their letters were in their respective spots. This let me score each pair, so just sort by the score, and I have my preferred starter.
spoilers
spoilers
spoilers
spoilers
spoilers
So in the end, the top answer I got was "caret loins". This optimises both for greens and yellows, but ignores what might come next, and doesn't take into consideration the first result before giving the second, so it will be less efficient than the entropy-based one. However, I also made a quick script that filters by the results of the first two words, and just gives me all possible words that match the results, and I can usually make a decent guess based on how common I think the words are, and can usually get it in 3. Sometimes there will only be one word left anyway, which is fun. The best result I got was
ybbbb
ybbbb
ggggg
with 3 answers (homework: what words did it give me?), and I guessed correctly, however
bbyby
yybbb
ggggg
had only one answer (homework part 2: what was that answer?)

This strategy doesn't actually minimize E turns. It maximizes p turns < k. There is a cost to guessing as opposed to reducing entropy, the age-old exploration-exploitation trade-off.

This gives a class of strategies that maximizes p turns <= k where you greedy search the entropy tree until the last turn and guess the argmax on turn k. The greedy is the best you can do because of the entropy chain rule along with the fact that you can defer guessing to the last turn.
