couple thoughts on this super interesting video:

1. i know many of us play solely in hard mode ... i feel like normal mode may be trivial for a computer-directed program given that hard mode limits the amount of information to be gained per round via the degrees of freedom given by grey letters on previous guesses. an example of this would be if after 2 guesses, you end up with _AUNT, with G, H, J, V, T all still available. at that point you're down to luck to pick the correct word in the remaining amount of guesses. each hard mode guess will give you <1 bit of information until maybe hitting the correct answer.
2. an optimal method can mean different things to different people. some might want to always be able to solve the puzzle every time. others may want the average case to be between 2-3 guesses while being ok missing a few words here and there. strongly defining what is optimal might be useful to listeners, or at least noting how different definitions of optimal could lead to different solutions.

if you can assume the permissible use of the given set of possible solutions and using hard mode to optimally never lose, my guess is there's probably a tree-based solution built using brute force simulation. each node of the tree would be an eligible word list and a potential guess. each leaf would correspond to a result of a given guess (Green, Yellow, Yellow, Grey, Grey) for example. keeping the tree of height <= 6 would be the goal. the brute force part of the solution would be trying each of the eligible guesses in the word list of that node until the height requirement is achieved.

I'm a linguist (and recreational mathematician). I have a fair amount of input on the linguistic side of this. Namely that your first mistake was using the results of Mayzner's letter frequency analysis. For a start, it used a very small sample size (of about 20,000 words) that ended up getting close but not accurate to the true letter frequency of English. We've done way better since then. In particular, Peter Norvig used Google corpus data to get a sample size of hundreds of billions of words.

And even though that one is more accurate, it is also very important to point out that that is an absolute frequency; not the variant frequency. There are 3 types of letter frequencies. The absolute frequency is that of usage, where, for example, "the" being a common word with high repetition means that it increases the frequency of T, H, and E. That isn't applicable to Wordle, because Wordle only considers each word once, and each is equally probable (discounting that previous words won't appear again). Instead, the variant frequency is the one that would apply to Wordle. The variant frequency is that which looks at all words in the language, including each variation of the word (e.g. "bright" and "brightly"), and each only once. It gives a different distribution. The third type of frequency is the root frequency, which looks at only root words without prefixes and suffixes (e.g. "bright", but not "brightly"), to take out the effect that regular plurals and gerunds and so on have on the letter frequency.

The other problem though, is that those letter frequencies aren't looking at only the 5-letter words in the language. The list of 5-letter words has a different distribution than all words.

I actually ran letter frequency analysis on Wordle's list of answers, and there are two to consider:

1.) The basic, upfront letter frequencies, which is:
EAROTLISNCUYDHPMGBFKWVZXQJ

and 2.) The frequency not of the letters, but of the words that contain those letters, which is more useful for Wordle's mechanics, and is:
EAROTLISNUCYHDPGMBFKWVXZQJ

This is actually the strategy I use, mostly because it is very easy to reference. It keeps it a casual game without having to do a lot of calculation each round, or each game. And it works beautifully. I use "orate" as my starter guess. I haven't gone higher than 5 guesses yet. Personally, I also play on hard-mode, with additional self-imposed rules, like requiring that correct letters in the wrong space not be guessed in that same space again on subsequent guesses. Because it is known to be incorrect. Default hard-mode doesn't impose that. I also only play using Words in the game's answer library. I reference it to be sure. I'm aware that it is possible that both of these rules (and even hard mode rules) could be preventing guesses that would convey more information, but I'm a bit of an all-or-nothing minmaxer, and, to me, a guess that can't be the answer is a wasted guess.

I also came up with a hypothetical way to find an - arguably - best word, but it would require programming skills that I don't have. It would be to match each word as a first guess against every word as the answer and look at all of the possible outputs each guess-and-answer pair would generate, and then to tally how many possible words each of those outputs could be, and then choose for the first guess whichever word has the lowest maximum number of possible words that its possible outputs would reduce to, and if multiple have the same lowest maximum, take whichever has the lowest average number of possible words it can reduce the list to. It may not be the statistically most optimal strategy, but it would be more pleasing, and I believe probably less likely to run out of guesses. But again, my extra-hard-mode rules might effect that.

I think one solution to get better score is to shift strategy as you go. You're being greedy by picking a word from the "most probable" list as opener and #2, very unlikely to win and forfeiting useful information because the most helpful openers may be very improbable to be answers. So - open with full set weighed only by entropy, and restrict to "more frequent words" as your entropy drops: if first guess was very good, you may try to go for score of 2, weighing the choice by frequency. If the first guess was poor, pick maximum entropy for guess 2 - essentially split the process into narrowing it down phase, where the word is most helpful, and guessing phase, where the word is most likely.

in terms of permutations
for 5 letter words, there are 26^5 = ~ 11 mil words.
for the complete grey word you rule out the possibility of 5 letters, which makes the options as 21^5 = ~ 4 mil words
for every green match we reduce the power by 1, so 2 matches means 21^3 = ~9k words. i would then use human common sense to guess the most common and correctly sounding word

First, I don't believe the official game allows guesses which don't match already identified green squares, or include the letters in already identified yellow squares. One you have a green E in the third square, all guesses must have an E in the third square. Once there is a yellow S all guesses must have an S. However, if a T has been rejected, subsequent guesses may still have T's, even though those will also be rejected.

But that aside, the entropy minimizing algorithm puts no weight on solving the puzzle in the next guess. I'd prefer guesses which not only reduce entropy, but additionally have a chance of solving the puzzle in the present guess. This can be accomplished with a simple constraint that each guess needs to meet the existing constraints (no letters which have already been rejected).

ADDED: I wrote this comment before finishing the video and I see you later address this issue, to minimize the expected # of guesses rather than strictly minimizing entropy.

There's an extra bit (pun intended) of info that could improve your algorithm. Look at the bits that consonants vs. vowels yield.
Most people try to maximize the vowels count in their first guess, but that's the opposite of optimal. Vowels give relatively little information. It's guaranteed that at least 1 of 5 vowels will be in any English word of any length (discounting onomatopoeias and 2 borrowed Welsh words). You get a lot more information by confirming or eliminating consonants (especially if you minimize the most common of them, R, S, and T, in your first guesses).

Kombu is a Japenese word. You might recognize it as the first part of the word "kombucha," literaly "kombu tea."
EXCEPT! Here's a fun fact, the thing English speakers now call "kombucha" has NOTHING to do with kombu. 昆布 "kombu" is a type of seaweed, and in Japanese 昆布茶 "kombu-cha" is a tea-like drink made with that seaweed. It is NOT the fermented tea drink that has gotten so popular in the west. The use of the word "kombucha" for a fermented drink seems to have come as a complete misunderstanding. In Japanese, the fermented tea drink English speakers call "kambucha" is actually called "kōcha-kinoko" which is "black tea mushrooms."

It's true that entropies can be added together, but only if they are entirely independent. If the two signals you're quantifying as entropy have any correlation (or more formally covariance), then their entropy is reduced, possibly to no more than one of the signals because the other is redundant. For example, if in a very silly language every word that had an "a" also had a "b", then the entropy of the two does not add together; when we know a word contains "a" there is no entropy required to know it also contains "b".

I'm not a mathematician and this is probably not the correct formal way to express the idea. I learned this limitation from the old days of Bayesian machine learning (e.g. the very first spam filters) where "naive Bayesian classification" assumes that all signals are independent. It explicitly acknowledges that this is an approximation with inaccuracy you can't quantify without computing all covariance between all combinations of all signals, which quickly becomes computationally intractable with diminishing returns.

Modern methods like deep neural nets strike a balance where the most significant informational relationships can be captured implicitly, while the finite complexity/resource budget cuts off the long tail of measurable but unjustifiable connections.

That said, massive kudos for saying you don't want to use the answer list in your analysis. I also wrote a program which plays a large dictionary but I evaluate it against the known answer list to see how it would perform if playing from start to finish. My approach is completely different and I don't think it's better, but it's fantastic that so many different approaches can be applied to this problem and compared fairly empirically. I've spent more time on this than on all of Advent of Code combined because of how deep the rabbit hole of improvement is :)

This video just happened to come out at the same time I was coming up with my own Wordle-solving algorithm: instead of minimizing the average number of guesses, I used minimax to optimize the worst-case scenario. On each turn, I do the following:

- Consider all possible words as guesses, including those that are no longer candidates with the information known
- For each word in the list, assign a score equal to the number candidate words left in the worst-case scenario (i.e. group the remaining candidates into buckets based on the color pattern they would give for the guess being considered, and use the size of the largest bucket as the score)
- Guess whichever word scores lowest (in case of a tie, favor words that are themselves candidates, and if still tied, choose the one that comes first alphabetically)

Since I didn't want to see the actual Wordle list, I started by using all 8937 five-letter words in TWL06; with this as the possible word list, I found "serai" to be the best starting guess and got an average of 4.12 guesses, with 17 words that took more than 6 guesses... all of which are either plural nouns or -s verbs ("zills" was the only word that took 8 guesses).
If I narrow this list down to the 3841 five-letter words that are among the 50000 most common English words (according to hermitdave's list on github), it goes down to 3.86 guesses on average, never takes more than 6 guesses (with 38 words taking exactly 6), and likes "arose" as an opener.
Using random 2315-word subsets (the same size as the Wordle list) of that smaller list, the average tends to vary between 3.59 and 3.66, with 6 guesses being quite rare.

So the expected score of my version isn't too far off from "version 2" in the video, but it seems to do better at avoiding the dreaded combo breaker.

Some thoughts on CRANE as first guess...

I usually guess stare first (an anagram of tares, which your first algorithm likes) but started guessing crate, with the reasoning that a C often comes with an H or K, so finding a C feels like it gives more information even though it's a less likely letter. Essentially, letters that are weighted towards appearing in certain types of words or in certain letter combinations should be more valuable guesses than their simple frequency should predict. C is probably at a sweet spot where it's not too uncommon a letter, and enjoys a big boost from giving you a lot of bonus information if you do find one.

Further to this, if you have, say, two certain letters that often appear in combination, it makes sense strategically to include one of these letters and not both in an early guess, as the odds of these letters appearing in the word are far from being independent odds, so guessing one gives you information on the probability of the other - bonus information from just one guessed letter. Hence, since CH and CK are very common associations of letters in common English words, guessing a C but not an H or a K in your first word seems to make a lot of sense from an information standpoint, and I'm not surprised that an algorithm found that guessing a word containing a C first was smart, despite C being quite a way down the letter frequency list.

Does your system take into account the value of a green letter vs. a yellow one?  A green letter reduces entropy significantly more.  For example, if you get a yellow 'a' as the first character, you leave yourself with 768 possible correct answers.  By contrast, a green 'a' in the first position reduces it to 141 possible answers.  It seems like the algorithm could be improved by using the frequency with which a given letter appears in a particular position in the answer list.

I think youtube ate my comment but my attempt at this was definitely less sophisticated: My heuristic was just the sum of the probabilities of each letter (how likely each letter is to occur in each position based on the word list), pruning the word list based on the clues provided and then recalculating the heuristic for the new list. I didn't consider 0 probability guesses because I wanted it to work for hard mode (where you must use the clues from previous guesses for subsequent guesses)

Entropy is probably a better heuristic but I'm not sure how much better it is.

> Kombu, whatever that means

It's dried seaweed used in Japanese cooking, commonly to make dashi (a savoury soup stock); this can be done either by heating it in water or via "cold brew" (leaving it in the fridge steeped in water for up to 12 hours). It can be used as-is for a vegan option, but tends to be a tad one-dimensional; often another method of making dashi is included. This can be katsuobushi (also known as bonito flakes; essentially fermented fish flakes) which is done essentially the same way (you take the already heated kombu dashi and add your bonito flakes, heating again until the flavor has seeped into the dashi and then removing the flakes afterward), but I tend to prefer cold brew (less washing up!) so I combine it with shiitake dashi instead. This is as simple as adding dried shiitake mushrooms to the cold brew alongside the kombu; as a bonus, the mushrooms will rehydrate and can be used in whatever dish you're preparing (I'm an Udon fellow myself, but there are a lot of ways to use dashi; it's very much a staple of Japanese cooking)

For more information visit Just One Cookbook, a Japanese cooking site that finally got me into making decent meals. I originally went there to learn how to make udon, but there's a lot of very simple, very tasty recipes if you have a nearby asian grocer (if you can get your hands on dashi miso paste that shit's practically magic) as well as more complex options for the more ambitious chef and some history and context to boot.

So there are two different ways to play Wordle. On hard mode, your guesses must all be in the short list of words that can be correct answers. In that mode, it is known that a strategy exists which always wins within five guesses and that no strategy exists which can always win within four guesses.

On normal mode, your guesses come from the long list, which makes the game easier to play but more computationally intensive to solve optimally. You could of course always just follow the hard mode strategy, but you should be able to do much better. To my knowledge, it is not yet known if a strategy exists that always wins within four guesses. However, it is known that no strategy exists which always wins within three guesses (an exhaustive search shows the optimal strategy for winning by turn 3 does so about 60% of the time).

So a strategy optimized for worst-case performance might take up to four guesses or up to five; we aren't sure yet.

i usually just go with Route as my first guess, and Ayins as my second guess. This eliminates all vowels, as well as N, R, T, and S, which are 4 of the most common consonants.

From there I can usually figure it out, or if I didn't get enough information, I'll try to use another word that uses as many unique letters that weren't already included.

For instance, today's word.

Route had no matches (fairly uncommon)
Ayins had the I green, and the S yellow.

So, my third word I guessed Flick.

The F is gray, but the L and K are yellow, meaning it is _ _ I _ _ and there is an S, K, and L in there. S and K aren't in the 5th spot, and L isn't in the second spot.

My strategy is to use 3 words that have no letters in common and then start from there. So I always do Audit Perky Clown. I get all the vowels and 10 of the 21 consonants. And I specifically didn’t use S, so I kinda have 10 consonants left and a bunch of positional data. From there I can start trying to guess what words are possible with the notes I have. At least 10 letters that are not in the word and up to 5 letters that are in the word.
With my 4th guess I have 3 strategies.
1) if I have a lot of correct guesses (greens not yellows) I’ll just go straight for the word
2) if I have a lot of hints (yellows) I try words that shift around those letters with only 11 unknown consonants to add in there
3) if I get almost no hints or correct guesses, I focus on maximizing as many of the remaining 11 consonants as I can. Letters like Z, X, and Q are gimmes that basically aren’t gonna show up, so the letters I have left are S,D,F,G,H,J,V,B,M. I usually use SIGHT for 3 extra consonants (and the common S) and then I should have enough information to get the word in 2 tries.
After today’s word (2/6/22) I get most of my guesses on word 5

You can refine your strategy with the following: if the word in the suggested guess has letters that has been guessed previously, then replace it with other letters. In the end, you want to guess an unknown 5-letter word, so you must first nail down what are the actual letters, so reguessing a letter is essentially meaningless and waste a valuable space. Then, after each guess, given the known yellowed or greened letters, the program should try to arrange them (with repeat) to see if they form an actual word by comparing it against the dictionary. You might be able to go even further by using the fact that every word has at least one a,e,i,o,u (or y) and they rarely appear consecutively. Even better, I think most 5-letter actual words have at most 2 vowels.

I hope that future teachers start teaching the meaning of entropy in the original, meaningful, simple way.  Entropy is the number of possible patterns (microstates) you can get with a given set of elements (macrostate).  Basically, it's how much variety there is.  The more elements you have, the higher the entropy.  Start with 10 coins and flip them, and you get an entropy related to 10.  Start with 100 coins and your entropy is related to 100.  There really isn't anything any more complicated about it.  Or at least there doesn't need to be for basic understanding.  Though you can add the option to measure the general patterns that don't involve specific orders.  Which would be where you have 9/10 heads being "higher entropy" than 1/10 heads, though this is a less useful way to think about entropy, as far as I'm concerned.

Data Scientist here:
Just wanted to add another perspective on entropy & the way we quantify information, as this topic is often fairly confusing for beginners.

So 1, where did all this theory & stuff come from? Information theory comes from trying to measure the efficiency of communication of information.

So the key idea is that, if we want to quantify information, really what we're doing is trying to measure how well one actor is communicating to another actor about an event.

So the two actors need to come up with some dictionary, or what is often called an "encoding" in order to communicate events to one another.

The the second key idea, is that It takes more energy to communicate with more symbols ("symbols" could be words, bits, smoke signals, whatever is your base unit of information).

Therefore, our objective is to assign the least amount of symbols to all the possible events, so we should encode according to how common different events are. More common events, should use less symbols.

The inverse of a probability has this great name, called "the surprisal", the idea is that the higher the number, the more "surprising" an event is. Like if I were to tell you the sky just instantly changed from blue to magenta, that event would have a wildly high surprisal, because it has a really low probability.

The reason we put a log on the surprisal is to get "how many symbols do we need in order to communicate this event?", the base of your log determines the number of symbols available to you, most commonly we use base 2 because we're usually thinking of this in bits.

The entropy of a probability distribution is the average number of bits required to communicate events in said probability distribution.

Hope someone else found that interesting! None of this stuff made sense to me until I understood that.

It seems as though this matches the form of a Linear Programming problem, as we are trying to maximize information gained from a wordle word given the constraints of wordle.
If you could write the objective function you are maximizing and the constraints in standard form, then you would just apply the Simplex Algorithm on it to yield a Linear Time Solution for the optimal word to choose from.
You also could modify the algorithm to give you a list of Feasible Solutions as well as the optimal one.

First off, great video.

The current title is "The Mathematically optimal Wordle strategy". I think that this video merely proposes the mathematically optimal greedy algorithm for wordle, and not the absolute best. The analogy to information theory is great. The way I view the optimal algorithm for Wordle is one that takes all Wordle states as a graph, and connects them such that A points at B if the word you guess at A could lead to the state B, and all leaf nodes (full word state) are part of the graph. Then you rank each possible graph based on your criteria for what makes the optimal graph (smallest maximum depth, average depth, etc). This is similar to compression algorithms in that it could be viewed very similar to how a huffman table is, except instead of binary 1s or 0s, it's each 5-letter word. And these huffman trees are usually built by a greedy algorithm similar to the one you've proposed in this video, but it doesn't necessarily mean it's the optimal one overall. I just thought it was interesting that something else in the information theory box would be so appropriate for this conversation, but only after watching your video did I understand how they came together.

Something I am trying to figure out in this example is why I dislike starting with "crane" so much. I think it's the wrong choice, and I think why explains something about the algorithm a human player uses versus what the machine is doing.

For me, when I try and look at a word given specific possibilities, I am not looking at it as a string of text but as a string of sounds, which is important here. Crane is difficult to start with because it doesn't narrow many things down phonotactically: the two consonants at the start are only a valid consonant cluster in a handful of words, and putting the vowel in the 3rd position doesn't provide any information about whether there is a consonant cluster at the beginning. This is why I like to start with "paste", because if the A is in the word and placed correctly it negates any word starting with a consonant cluster. On the other hand, if it is not, the s-t-p combination provides two valid consonant clusters and their order: if s-t or s-p is in the word, it's likely that they are at the beginning or end in that order. On the other hand, if t-p is in the word, there is very little likelihood that they are together at all.

This strategy also extends to the letter C in general, which can be pronounced in several ways which also leaves several sets of words open which are difficult to search through mnemonically.

Because of these factors I think that the question of what is the optimal word to start with is different for a computer compared to a human - a computer in general has a great ability to search for all words that could be the answer, but needs to be told what the probabilities are. On the other hand, a human is much better at predicting what words might be next but can have trouble interpreting the data it gets from its previous guesses unless the guesses are formatted to be easily interpreted.

I think it would be interesting to try and build a computer program that uses a human-like algorithm that works using phonetics and letter clusters instead of the string-focused approach used here, I would be interested to see if the average score could be improved by that sort of process.

More nuggets for everyone: each configuration of Wordle has a temperature!

As you may know, especially after watching this video, originally when the idea of entropy was created we only used it when we discussed heat and engines because we thought that that was the only context in which the concept applied. But eventually after we made the link between entropy and information we realized all kinds of systems have entropy.

But you may not know that temperature too has a more general definition outside the realm of what we perceive as "heat". There is such a thing as temperature in statistical mechanics, which does not lose it's meaning on small scales. And turns out that as long as you can define the idea of entropy for a system you can define temperature as well!


This is also part of why you can do things like assign a temperature to a black hole! It's because the informational notion of entropy is certain valid on that object.

This approach still uses a 'greedy' notion of entropy. An optimal algorithm would consider sequences of guesses as a whole. For example, a guess W1 might give you the most entropy reduction E1, but for all possible next guesses W2, the entropy reduction E1+E2 could be beaten by an alternative sequence that gets us E1'+E2', even if E1'<E1. Of course, this example just looks at a horizon of 2 guesses, but you'd need to run sequences till you're left with just one possible answer (or 0 bits of entropy).
Greedy comes close, but you can shave a little more off the expected number of guesses.

Minimax is an appropriate choice here. This is a wonderful job. I followed a similar approach, but opting not to use word frequency. I think the next logical step is to focus not on expected entropy, but on minimizing the maximum remaining entropy (maximizing the minimum information from the guess). It’s a slightly different approach, but one that fits with the goal of completing the challenge within a maximum of six guesses.

From a minimax standpoint “SERAI” maximizes the minimum information we obtain if we ignore the wordless target list. If we make use of the fact that we know the possible target words, it is actually “ARISE” that is our minimax choice, which is also a possible answer.

I think entropy is a great word for this. Wordle starts at near zero entropy, only having some entropy introduced by its restriction to 5 letter words. When someone starts to interact with it, it gains information about that interaction that can be observed and extracted. The wordle contains all of the information in its universe when solved (maximum entropy). Its really interesting and not intuitive the notion of "closer to the word", and wordle as you've posed it is such a great toy for thinking about it.

Rather than pull letter frequency from the dictionary, it's better to pull it from previous Wordle answers, because I've noticed that the Wordle answer is NEVER a four-letter plural (ex. nails; lions) or a 3rd-person present verb (ex. jumps; grabs). If it ends in S, it ALWAYS ends in a double-S (ex. floss; abyss; truss).

I start with CRUST because it uses 4/5 of the most common consonants. If the answer has a C or S, there's an 80% chance they're in the first or fourth spot, and are the two most common letters to be in the 1st or 4th spot. The R and T are less predictable, but are by-far most commonly in the 2nd and 5th spots, respectively. All vowels, except E, appear most commonly in the middle.

The other most-common consonant is L, but it's very random where it appears in the word, so I save it for later.

Awesome video! I think it's interesting to also consider different ways to quantify the goal of a Wordle bot other than just getting the lowest average score. Of course we know fewer guesses is better, but what else could be important?

Is it better to solve ten puzzles each in 3 guesses? Or five puzzles in 2 and the other five in 4?

Is an average of 3.5 with a 100% chance of completing the puzzle better or worse than averaging 3 but having a 5% chance to fail to solve the puzzle in the six allotted guesses?

Maybe one would design a bot that's intended to beat another player - to maximize the occurrences of solving the puzzle in fewer guesses than that person, without regard for the margin of how much the win is by.

It's subjective what's best to prioritize beyond minimizing the average score but I think it opens up lots of fun possibilities that would lead to unique Wordle algorithms.

Very interesting video as always. One thing that sticks out to me, is the use of expected entropy. Since we essentially are solving a stochastic optimization problem, it might be worthwhile to consider other approaches to assign real values to these random variables. For instance, instead of maximizing expected entropy, one could perhaps maximize the median entropy, or impose conditions on quantiles of the entropy. In this way, one could construct a more risk averse (/riskier) strategy, to reduce chances of using 4+ steps.

One thing i would question is whether the "average" score is what you are looking to optimise. Personally I prefer optimising the "worst" score, i.e. how many guesses it would take in the worst situation. There are a couple of advantages to this approach:
1 - in the real Wordle you would never lose, i.e. fail to guess in 6
2 - in a version where you were playing adversarially it is likely that the opponent chooses words that are uncommon (or of they are really dastardly then chooses words that your algorithm does worst on) in this case your "word frequency" approach fails as it gives the opponent a way to break your algorithm (to oppose that you need to assign each allowable word with equal probability).

I wrote code to do this based on taking a miax approach (i.e. minimum maximum number of possible words left), although I didn't consider the entropy of the remaining word list which would improve the code. Unfortunately my code is super slow to run :/

The timing of this video is amusing, because I just had a go at this myself yesterday. Not having all the mathematical and theoretical tools at my disposal, I initially tried keeping track of how many (remaining, valid) words contained a letter at a position. For example, at initialization, there are 141 answers with "A" in the first position. To select a guess, I perform a greedy search over the remaining possibilities by summing these values for each letter in the guess candidate at the according position. So, SLATE (which happens to be my code's first guess choice) is 1437=[366,201,307,139,424]. My reasoning here was that if I could guess the most common letter at each position, it's either likely to be correct (get a green, get closer to the answer fast) or rule out many words (with a black). This naive solution wound up with an average of about 3.681 turns to guess all the words, but the max guesses is 8. I was able to tweak it to solve them all in under 6 and keep a similar average (3.689) by taking a guess intended to disambiguate similar words.

I feel like there are some underlying ties between the approach you describe and my intuition here (in particular, my mental intuition valued selecting for flat distributions for some vague definition of that), but I'm not sure what causes them to differ so much in outcome; I wonder if there is something interesting to tease out here?

The most useful and enlightening definition of entropy I've ever encountered came from neuroscientist Terrence Deacon, who frames it as the dissipation of constraints. Anything at maximum entropy is maximally UN-constrained. Be it energy levels in the statistical distribution of particles in an ideal gas (Boltzmann) or the resolution of uncertainty in the answer of any given question (Shannon). It also helps to frame how entropy doesn't simply rely on the contents of a container (2 black, and 2 red checkers on a 2 x 2 checker board, for example) but the possibility space conferred onto those arrangements by the SIZE of the container (considerably larger if those same checker pieces end up transposed onto a standard 8 x 8 board). Constraints man, they're big time (gravity vs. Inflation being my all time fav example).

This sort of invites a follow-up discussion on greedy vs optimal solutions - using negative entropy here is just a heuristic for how reduced the problem is, however the size of the remaining search space is not a direct measure of progress: two different search spaces of the same size could have significantly different difficulty in solving. This is because there might not exist specific words which allow you to partition the remaining search space efficiently.

Bader-Meinhof phenomenon: yesterday, I was watching a Genetically Modified Skeptic video about heresiology and the host quoted Tertullian calling then followers of Marcion of Sinope. I looked it up: common vetch (Vicia sativa), a weed that in Tertullian’s time, posed a significant danger to farms, as it resembled other, economically valuable plants. The weed in Jesus’ Parable of the Weed (Matthew 13:24–43) is translated as “tare” in the King James Bible, although it might have been the related darnell.
Today, I watch 3Blue1Brown and the word “tares”, which, as Grant “helpfully” explains, means common vetch, appears several times.
Of course, a plural form of species of grass is unusual. How often do you hear “wheats”, or “corns”, or even “vetches”? The word might be better analyzed as the third-person single indicative of the verb “tare”, meaning to zero, said of scales and similar instruments. On high-qualify laboratory scales, there is typically a tare button, which tells the scale’s mechanism to treat whatever is on the scale now as nothing, and only weigh what is subsequently added.

One thing I would find interesting is an algorithm that approaches the problem in a more risk-averse way by incorporating the variance of entropy as well as the expected entropy. For example, a word may remove 5 bits on average but have a very polarized distribution in comparison to a word that removes 4.9 bits on average and is unlikely to deviate very far from that number when the letters are revealed. Perhaps we could place more value on maximizing the rate of success rather than the average score. The game isn’t designed with this concept in mind, but it’s one other way the game could be “scored.”

Of course, the game gives you enough guesses to determine the answer almost every time without any consideration for risk, but what if we only had 3 guesses?

This is probably the best Wordle program I have seen but it still has a problem which is nagging me. It assumes that maximising entropy is always the best thing to do. Now for a matter of practical implications it is basically the best approach. But in an ideal world, a word with less entropy might actually be a better choice. (By better, I mean results in fewer average remaining guesses to reach the answer). The reason for this is that because of the restricted possible guesses in wordle, certain word sets may be easier or harder to get information out of. I assume this is what Grant was trying to address in his approach looking two moves ahead. E.g. a guess might give you 5 bits of information, but on the next guess you expect to only get 3 bits. Whereas another guess might give you 4 bits now, but you expect to be able to get 5 bits on you next guess. To really have the optimal strategy you would want to look all the way to the end of the game to account for all of this, but that would probably be to intensive for a computer program so perhaps a different approach is needed. Or perhaps its just not possible with current hardware (this is my suspicion). Either way, great program and interesting video!

I made a bot too. I tested every possible word against every possible answer and bucketed the responses Wordle would give you. My bot concluded "raise" is the best starting word as it most evenly distributes those buckets. From there it plays guesses to try and maximise the number of words ruled out by that guess. As a result, it solves every Wordle in 5 or fewer guesses - and only 9% of words need that fifth guess. It's about 40% each for 3 or 4 guesses, and the rest is 2 guesses or the word "raise" itself.

I have a question for you, first here is what prompts me to ask this question:
A file on a computer is a bit sequence. Since most files are constructed through rules, there usually is a certain regularity to those bits, ex: 00000111110000011111. There is a clear pattern in that sequence, if it continued on for 20kb I could just say (5x0+5x1)x2000, of course it would be in binary so a bit longer, but still waaay shorter than 20kb, essentially what I did is compressed my file. I remember in class learning that the theoretical limit for compression is maximum entropy, or in other words the bit sequence is so "random" it is 100% information, no pattern.

Ok now I want to think of the heads or tails problem in terms of bit. There is a common trend amongst probability teachers to ask "which is more likely? 00000000000000000000 or 101000100101001011111", and then everyone picks the 2nd one and they say "AH sucker, they are both equally likely".

My question is: is that really so?? Because the second sequence contains way more information than the first one, it's "incompressible". So if you think about it in terms of information, when we detect patterns in the output, we intuitively associate this with a lower likelyhood, cause I think we do understand on an intuitive level that entropy [almost] always increases. So if instead of calculating the probability of a specific sequence, but instead calculate the probability to yield a certain quantity of information (which is how I think we all understand that problem the first time we hear it) I think there is an answer to this question. Maybe this is all a wording issue, maybe it would be correct to say that even if both sequences are equally probable, one is more "plausible", anyways, is there any truth in what I'm saying or am I just completely lost?

I'm unsure about one thing, and that is if that optimizing for the maximum expectation information of the current try is optimal, instead of optimizing for a sequence of tries. Imagine that for example, after the first try you don't get the hints of wordle, but you need to enter the next guess. In that case you would need to optimize not for the individual use, but for the sequence of tries. Maybe "slate" maximize your expected information for a single try, but if you have to use two sequential words without a hint it would be "crane" and "dough" (the words are just examples, not true) instead of "slate" and the next one in the list.

Although is true that the hints change everything, I don't know if is true that the optimization for the immediate try is the best way to proceed, since you need to assume that the game is likely to continue.

This is effectively a greedy algorithm, choosing the guess which optimizes the immediate next state of the game. 2-step lookahead is a lot better, but 4 or 5 would be needed to literally "solve" the game and determine the exact "mathematically optimal" strategy, and I think it might just be too computationally expensive to figure it out for real.

I always open with AEONS, because it has three of the five common vowels and two quite frequent consonants and it provides incredibly solid foundation

After that, unless I get something solid to work with, I follow it up with THICK and/or LUMPY (the latter is especially useful if none of the first vowels fit) which together cover all the remaining vowels and some of the more common consonants. Usually these are enough to get the word right on the 3rd–4th attempt, and in any case they are almost certain to provide a lot of clues for further guessing

This might not be the most mathematically optimal strategy, but I think that if you play without dictionary/bot there are some additional factors that make things more human-solvable, such as knowing the word's vowels and knowing whether there's an H in the word (along with some of S, T, C) as it's the one letter most frequently appearing in digraphs and knowing whether it's in the word helps roughly outline the set of possible consonant sounds which really helps when rolling around possibilities on your tongue

Something that I see no one taking about but has given me good results (better than 3.4 average guess anyway) is prioritising consonants over vowels. Simply because there are more consonants to eliminate, so eliminating them gives you more information. I never start with a word that has more than 1 vowel, and depending on the outcome of that, I usually do the same for my second guess too. Having then eliminated 8 consonants after 2 guesses I find I get it on the third guess nearly as often as the 4th.

At 25:35 , you have the opportunity to make bots that go after different goals. An interesting choice would be to minimize E[score + \lambda variance] where \lambda is a small, positive, tunable parameter. Large \lambda would result in a bot that avoids variance and therefore plays more consistently. Small \lambda results in a bot that takes "calculated risks" to get more "birdies" and "eagles" (to borrow more golf lingo).

I think your strategy is wrong.  Wordle isn't a game about guessing words, it's about guessing letters.  Focusing on the word frequencies are hampering your strategy. Hard mode essentially makes you use clues you’ve learned (although, again, the actual website is quite lenient with its own rules), so if you get a green/yellow/gray, you must keep that letter there/use that letter in your future guesses in a new position/can’t use that word at all, respectively. While playing the game, just like you considered the "common word probability", I consider the "common character probability" as well. I propose scoring the words on the basis of how frequent each letter comes at each of the 5 positions in all the 5-letter words.
For example, you mentioned the NAILS vs SNAIL choice. SNAIL has an A in the middle (as in ~1200 5 letter words), whereas NAILS has A on the 2nd position (as in ~2100 5 letter words). Clearly, the A in NAILS gives you higher information (getting those greens on the board).

This was a nice video, but the title is very misleading. There's nothing "mathematically optimal" about this heuristic. There's an implicit assumption in the video that's probably incorrect that smaller spaces of remaining solutions necessarily take fewer guesses. It may, for example, be that a word that results in slightly larger buckets of solutions has easier buckets to solve. The optimal solution is a dynamic programming solution that works out for each bucket, how many guesses it will take (either on average or worst case, whatever you're optimizing) to solve it. Again, great video, a great heuristic, but just because it has mathematics in it, doesn't make it "mathematically optimal".

I absolutely love this video! The content is fantastic and timely. However, I think it's a mistake to call the quantity "entropy" when it is actually the negative entropy. Notably you say "maximize entropy" throughout the video, when such algorithms are generally considered to minimize entropy. The reason it's potentially confusing for lay people as well is that they are likely to be familiar with the second law of thermodynamics, so the difference between increasing and decreasing entropy has significant intuitive implications. Increasing entropy is greater unpredictability, corresponding to a higher number of potential states. Lower entropy is greater predictability from fewer possible states.

My initial approach to this algorithm would be similar to Jan Misali's algorithm for hangman.
Start with a set of legal words, and analyse the most common letter within these worlds. Then create a subset of this set of legal words that contains this letter. Iterate this process until you get a suitable first guess. Then take that guess, use the information provided by the green yellow and grey information to update the set of legal words.

Your explanation of the game's rules contains a significant error. It turns out that there isn't a SINGLE way to "mark" a guess. You never mentioned this. E.g., the same "word guess" could have more than one (even more than two!) possible colour results. For example, if you guess "QUITS" but the answer is SASSY, the yellow marker for "S" could be in any one of three different possible positions. (So your code is flawed.) So in fact, if you were "the player" providing the colour results, there's actually a STRATEGY for providing a valid colour answer (which could be to provide the least amount of information.) Also, I wish to claim that information theory isn't even the BEST way to solve this puzzle. My code gets results that seems to be as good as yours, but doesn't use information theory, at least not formal the way you do.
When I saw the Games People Play video on this subject, I just knew there had to be a cleverer way to do this. I was not disappointed!

Pleased to see at 17:21 that you picked up on the fact that Wordle does not quite work the way most people assume it works, in that a grey cell does not necessarily mean that letter is not in the answer. It depends how many times the letter is in the answer versus in the guess. Most of the early programs written to solve Wordle (including my own) got that detail wrong, so they were actually solving a slightly different game.

At 2:49 you make a mistake many people make: you used the letters' frequencies in English *text*. However, text contains lots of repetition, in which small words like "the", "he", "she", "they", etc skew the results, for example overstating the frequency of the letter H. But even the "dictionaries" list wouldn't have been the best option here, because words of different lengths are also more or less likely to contain certain letters. Of course, using the lists that Wordle actually uses solves this problem.

In my own attempts, I only looked at five letter words from a dictionary, calculating letter frequencies for each position in the word. The best opening word I came up with based on those findings is "coats", followed by "urine". As I used the dictionary instead of the wordle lists, these should also be future-proof in case Wordle changes its lists.

Let me propose an alternative approach.
What you are doing is making a guess. Depending on the answer, you are presented with the opportunity of making another guess, and there are lots of choices. You could get the correct answer, and you stop. If not you make a selection from a set of guess and repeat. That is a tree.
So what's do you want to do? You want to minimise the average depth of the trees, if you assume that each word is equally likely.
That's not quite the same thing as the algorithm, because it involves looking ahead more than one step.
It's just like a chess program. No chess program just looks at the board and makes a decision. It creates a tree, and using an algorithm called min-max, looks ahead.

I programmed a script a while ago that would solve this. It would take all five letter worlds in the dictionary, assign each letter the value of it's frequency, then sort the list after each word's total value. The first word in the list was ESSES since both E and S scored very high on the frequency. Since I want as much information as possible, I made sure each guess would be the first word in the list that didn't have any duplicate letters. My first guess is now always AEROS and my program usually solved the puzzle in between 3-4 tries. Rarely 5, but there are cases where i messes up since words like "shark", "shard", and "sharp" are so alike.
Whenever I play, I have a self imposed “house rule” to start with a different First Word each day to keep it interesting. Wondering if anyone else does this?
